issue.title: do transfer (download and send) via memory... without saving to local file...

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
I think @reidsunderland was talking about this. Someone has a case where they want to transfer from an upstream source to a downstream destination. They don't want to write the file locally, because it's essentially just a buffer for the transfer.

Was talking today with a client, and they want this for S3 uploading... that is, download the file to a buffer, and then upload each buffer to the destination.

I think this could be done with an subscribe, by sub-classing sarracenia.transfer class, to override the on_data entry point to write the data to a pre-established output file descriptor.

along with a flowcb to:
* on_start to establish a connection to S3...
* after_accept to create/open the new object/file establish the file descriptor for the on_data to write to.
* after_work to close the completed object/file.
*on_stop to tear down the connection.

So that way, the entire transfer is only using one memory buffer.
 
anyways, that's one guess at how to do it... it might be wrong.

On the one hand, this means roughly (by eye) 30 ish dependencies. and those deps aren't trivial... 
including: llvm, libboost, matplotlib, scipy, pandas, openblas  ... I guess the good side is performance is likely to be good because there is a lot of leveraging of high performance C libraries. There is also tornado? you need
a web framework to use a file system?  In total, it's pulling in 883 MB of dependencies.

Looking at redhat8, it does not show up at all.... so installing on redhat involves establishing a large venv (with a few gb of parallel environment for dependencies) or going with one of the python distributions like Anaconda.  

In a Scientific python context, this actually isn't bad... most of this stuff should be on hand anyways.  Sarracenia is often deployed as a system tool, however, not an application, and getting it installed at system level, such large dependencies will give a lot of people pause.

It might be nice to run ShellCheck on sr_insects, implement it's suggested fixes and then set up the same Action to automatically run it.

Slightly related to https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/issues/82.

comment.body:
note that for most of our purposes, we want to save locally, because there are 10 destinations for each source product, so going via memory would mean retrieving from source 10 times.  So it's not great for many cases,
but in cases, where we truly deliver to one location, and where if the downstream is having an issue, it is ok to be bothering upstream, then this model is helpful.

issue.title: v2 issue endlessly declaring queues with empty queue name

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: Priority 3 - Scary
labels.description: worrisome impact... should study carefully

labels.name: v2only
labels.description: only affects v2 branches.

issue.body:
I deployed a config on ddsr and when the config was started on ddsr5, instance 02 somehow ended up with an empty queue name and caused an infinite loop of declaring a queue with an empty name.

Instance 01 on ddsr5 was fine, and both instances on all the other nodes were also fine.

See bladoc #1579
@junhu3

comment.body: If there was something wrong with the config files, instance 1 would have been affected... I've never seen anything close to that.

issue.title: AM protocol driver

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body: To help with decommissioning Sundew, but not lose interop with MM, then we could make a sender/receiver for AM sockets...

comment.body: The stuff being put in the AM header is the ONLY way to separate the bulletins.  The AM header gives the length of the message in bytes. and you have to read that many bytes and then stop.  Any later bytes are the start of the header of the next message,... If you don't read the right number of bytes... it is hopeless... you will miss the header and I don't think there is any way to re-sync, and AM protocol doesn't have any elements that would allow a re-sync.  You need to parse the header correctly, assign the bytes correctly.

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... so the  management ui does not work at all in this case, sr sanity will kill it, 
status says they are stray, audit does not work... etc...

Question: what should we do in this case?

options:


Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
---------------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way. Make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
----------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.

Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?
(guess: subscribe, unless component directory provided? ... option add a "--component" command line option, which defaults to "subscribe" )

trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body:
so sarra runs per user... when you do sr_subscribe start xx   it is running as your current user, not root.  What is the meaning of the files in /etc/sr3 ?  to provide site defaults, I guess? Other reasons?

so... today... we match ~/.config/sr3/x/y with the state files in ~/.cache/sr3/x/y   where we put state files (recording the .pid, queue file name, persist the cache, etc...) in this new search path world, what does sr3 status show?

All configs in every part of the search path?   when someone does a *foreground* or a *start* and the config file is NOT in the ~/.config tree, I guess we should copy it there once we find it... and then sr status and friends will work unchanged... 

Is that the right idea? or should there be some other way of doing things.

issue.title: AM protocol driver

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body: To help with decommissioning Sundew, but not lose interop with MM, then we could make a sender/receiver for AM sockets...

comment.body:
So @kurt2x has a long standing wish to have an amserver, like on MetManager, where anyone just connects to a socket, and starts sending data.  with Sundew, we never had that, one would just pick a port, and a single process (pxReceiver) would service a single connection on the defined port.

What @andreleblanc11 has implemented right now is like pxReceiver, it accepts a single connection and processes it.  To get amserver like behaviour, we need to follow the traditional (if obscure) C daemon service pattern (looking for links, I gave @andreleblanc11 one in teams, but can't find it now...)


to recap... what is needed for the amserver "forking" issue:

* in the on_start it does a bind. ONCE! then it loops:
   * it then does an accept.
   * increment an instance id for the child's use...
   * then you pid=fork().
   * the parent (pid!=0) then needs to:
        * close the accepted socket. and 
        * loop around again waiting on the next accept... (not bind.)
   * The child (pid==0) then needs to:
       * change to use the given instance id... which means:
       * logging to a file with the correct instance id.
       * writing the pid file for the instance, so that sr status|stop|sanity will find it.
       *then exit the loop and start processing messages...

so... all the instance and log stuff is set up in instance.py ... which calls flow.. so it isn't immediately obvious how to call the instance stuff from a flow... sigh... food for thought.
perhaps @reidsunderland has some ideas.

the log setup logic is kind of painful, it's in sarracenia.instance.start() ... I guess we can copy/paste, or might need to re-factor a bit...

issue.title: hierarchical configurations (getting rid of "components")

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

issue.body:
In the Development meeting on 2022/03/28, it was like a light-bulb was suddenly lit, and people understood that all the components are just the flow algorithm with different defaults for different settings.  People noted:
* it was hard to understand what "a component" is.
* It was kind of cool that they were all implemented by sub-classing sarracenia.flow.

Consensus seemed to be that getting rid of the concept of components would be a win.  but it's a bit late in the sr3 cycle for that.
(and it wasn't really possible until all the 1st round of re-factors was done, because it wasn't until the last re-factor of poll that this became true.  until then poll was a huge outlier in the sub-classing of flow, but now that flowcb/poll/__init__.py has taken the main body of poll, the ¨poll¨ flow is just a selection of callbacks, like the other components.  so now it should be possible.

comment.body:
so this is implemented in #575... the thing I noticed is that there are very common configurations, senders, watches, etc... and if we have a sub-directory for them, that denotes the same information as the include, but the name of the configuration does not have that information... so in many cases you end up writing configuration files named:   sender_....  that contain the option *include sender.inc*  so you are writing "sender" twice... which is worse from a DRY perspective.

ie.
You could have a:
```

      sender/hoho.conf
                <contains a normal sender config>

```

vs.

```
     sender_hoho.conf
                 include sender.inc
                <contains a normal sender config>

```
So in a very common case, you end up writing the component name twice instead of once.
big deal? dunno... 

hmm...I'm thinking to keep the directory stuff around as shorthand... 
* if the *last* directory in the config path matches a sub-class, then it is assumed to be that kind of flow.
* if not it defaults to a parent class (Flow) (or explicit specification with flowMain option.)

so then you can group things like:

```
    pitcher_use_case/
                          watch/
                                  server.conf
                                  client.conf
                        sender/
                                  push.conf
                       subscribe/
                                  pull.conf
                      bobo.conf
                      lala/
                              fifi.conf
```

resulting in sr status showing lines like:
```

pitcher_use_case/watch/server
pitcher_use_case/watch/client
pitcher_use_case/sender/push
pitcher_use_case/subscribe/pull
pitcher_use_case/flow/bobo
pitcher_use_case/lala/flow/fifi


```
optionally bobo and fifi could be in flow sub-directories...

but the idea of keeping both around, in the current implementation results in two implementations of shovel, winnow, report, post, and watch... DRY again... do we write more code to get rid of it?

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... so the  management ui does not work at all in this case, sr sanity will kill it, 
status says they are stray, audit does not work... etc...

Question: what should we do in this case?

options:


Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
---------------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way. Make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
----------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.

Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?
(guess: subscribe, unless component directory provided? ... option add a "--component" command line option, which defaults to "subscribe" )

trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body: Another question is there is a rudimentary search path for sr config files... should there be a formal search path? SR_CONFIG_PATH ? or something like that? and look in those directories when resolving an *include" ...

comment.body:
OK, people should have a look at the latest commit... and think if this is what people want?
Now the configuration is completely universal... a config file like:
```

flowMain subscribe

```

is a default subscriber file... in fact that is the content of the subscribe.inc file included in the last commit.  so all the old components can kind of disappear, and everything just becomes a flow,
some of them running different flowMains (that directive is only needed for the components that require subclasses (poll, sender, subscribe, sarra)  the rest don't even need that.

This still does not give us hierarchies, but we it means that we don't have to have a specific directory structure anymore. Everything can just be a flow.  So with the given patch, we now have the option of defining everything with config files, and reducing the number of classes.

We could re-arrange things in sr3 to... when converting, always re-write using flows and includes, instead of the current component mappings... it is just that it will cause a lot of work on the insects flow tests, as all the log files are likely to change.... unless we just make the names match...
hmm... could do that... dunno...

comment.body:
OK so I sat with @andreleblanc11  yesterday and we pair programmed for a bit.  He now has a flowcb plugin that works for accepting messages from a single connection, writing them to a file in a configured directory, and posting a message for the resultant local file.  We had to comment out the poll initialization in order to get it to work for our example, because:

* If we add that plugin into a poll, a poll wants to have a transfer protocol (that it connects to to list files on the remove resource.) so since there is no transfer protocol to connect to, the init fails.

* If we add it as a plugin into a shovel (or subscribe, or sarra, or winnow.) it wants a broker to connect to for upstream messages... so the connection to the upstream broker fails on startup.

* If we add it as a plugin for watch... hey that might work... we just have a watch with a plugin that writes to the watch directory... but again... it would be a watch with no watch... 

* we could try to use the parent class (sarracenia.flow) without any sub-class... but the whole cli is built around the concept of "component/config" (which is already something being called into question in: #575, and #494 ) 
*  we could add special logic for "flow" to be an implicit component, and call them flows.
*  to avoid having to deal with "no-component",  we could invent a kind of "vanilla" flow... a flow class with no default plugins.    That would start up, and run... but currently we have no way of using a something that isn't a "component" so we need to invent a new "vanilla" component?  "plain?" 
* We could do is just make a sub-class for Andre's thing am becomes a new components sr3 start amserver.

dunno... lots of options.. not sure which way to do... so far the most attractive thing to me is to futz with "flow" as an implicit component...

issue.body:
currently we use poll for remote resources, via sftp, ftp, and http with various web services.
For local file systems, we can use linux INOTIFY kernel facility, except in some case that does not work (e.g: in HPC where file i/o can happen on many nodes and must have watch running on all nodes as a consequence)  so we have the force_polling option in watch... which seems odd given the existence of the poll component... why don't we just use that? indeed... 

Need to investigate whether polling with a destination as a file url works, and if so, document it as another option.

It  seems inelegant for this not to work.

issue.title: should we make greater use of pathlib?

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

labels.name: Refactor
labels.description: change implementation of existing functionality.

issue.body:
The pythonic (>3.6) way to deal with paths, is to use pathlib, and Path objects. Path objects make paths for the current platform, but relative paths that go into messages are supposed to be standard (ie. use the forward slash, not backward.) so using pathlib on windows to create messages will result in different messages.  We want to create portable paths, not platform specific ones.

Would it be better to look at places where paths are manipulated and use paths.  It is used in a few places where final local filenames are created, but most of the code uses strings, out of fear and because the old code is pre 3.6.

commits.message: Reworked `sr3 stop` to use dangerWillRobinson as discussed https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/pull/578

pull_request.title: Reworked `sr3 stop` to use dangerWillRobinson
pull_request.body:
`sr3 stop` will never stop foreground instances, even if you specify `component/config`. A message is printed to let the user know about running foreground configs that were not stopped, and that they can use `--dangerWillRobinson` to stop them.

`sr3 stop --dangerWillRobinson` will always stop running foreground instances (in addition to daemon instances).

Also found that there was a piece missing from previous changes that I made to `sr3 stop`'s behavior. If the stop method started attempting to SIGKILL processes, it would report that foreground instances were not responding to SIGKILL, even though it was not trying to SIGKILL them. Now the processes that are not responding to SIGKILL are correctly reported (only daemone

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... Question: what should we do in this case?

options:

Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
--------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way.
make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
-------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the 
version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy
of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.
Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?


trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body: would be great to group co-dependent examples as trees of configuration files, instead of just individual examples in component directories.

comment.body:
so say somebody gives a cli:
```

% sr3 foreground kk.conf

```
kk.conf is a file in the current directory (call it the local version)

in option 2, one would assume that kk.conf is a subscribe, and therefore copy it to ~/.config/sr3/subscribe/kk.conf, and then run foreground normally.  If there already is a kk.conf in ~/.config/sr3/subsscribe? what do we do?

a) always copy the local one to config tree... (so the user does his editing normally, and when they restart it takes effect... which sounds sugary to me.) .... this is an implicit "add" ... equivalent to sr3 add kk.conf... followed by sr3 foreground subscribe/kk.conf ... hmm...

b) check the mtime of the local and config tree copies... only copy if the local one is newer... (same sugar as option b.)

c) ignore local copy if config version exists... insists on use of cli "edit" command to take effect. (no sugar, adds friction... that user must use cli "edit" interface.)


```

sr3 foreground poll/kk.conf subscribe/kk.conf

```

similar but extended for more files and components assuming you have subdirectories for configurations.

```

mynet/   
           poll/mynet.conf
           sarra/mynet.conf

```

could have a sub-directory and accept the entire tree....copy they entire tree to config tree... 
starts to resemble #494.

issue.title: poll behaviour in vip... not working quite right.
issue.body:
as part of working on https://github.com/MetPX/sr_insects/issues/16 In the flakey_broker test, we simulate the failure of two poll configurations that differ by their vip setting.  when the broker is shut down as part of the flakey_broker test, the vip settings of the two polls are exchanged, so that the active and passive roles of the two configurations are switched.  This role switch is repeated for each of the the broker shutdowns.

It has become clear that poll isn't dealing with broker failures quite right....

this is the initial problem statement from that issue:
```

 poll sftp_f62 posted 659  sftp_f63 posted 198 
test 20 FAILURE: poll sftp_f62+3	 (857) should have the same number of items of sender	 (1120)
test 21 success: poll sftp_f62+3	 (857) should see the same number of items as poll sftp_f62 posted	 (857)
test 22 FAILURE: subscribe q_f71	 (1714) should have the same number of items as poll sftp_f62+3 (857)

```

part1: noticed redundant posting (both participants in the poll posting):
```

fractal% grep 'after_post posted' poll_sftp_f63_01.log | sed "s/.*'path': '//" | sed "s/'.*//" | sort >poll_f63_posted_sorted.list
fractal% 
fractal% grep 'after_post posted' poll_sftp_f62_01.log | sed "s/.*'path': '//" | sed "s/'.*//" | sort >poll_f62_posted_sorted.list
comm -12 poll_f62_posted_sorted.list poll_f63_posted_sorted.list | wc -l

```
went into the log directory (~/.cache/sr3/log) after a run, and the above snippet prints the paths of files posted by each polling configuration.  Since the list is not zero... there is some redundant posting going on.

issue.title: review & further document flowcb/run.py

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

issue.body:
There was a long-standing wish for a generalized "please invoke this arbitrary script or binary" on receipt of a file or in other circumstances.  for sr3 we now have a first pass at such a module, called Flowcb.Run Please look at the source
for how it is used:

 https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/blob/v03_wip/sarracenia/flowcb/run.py

Questions:
  * currently uses subprocess.Popen for running per file stuff, but subprocess.run for other cases.  Are both necessary? do they work the same? example, with popen, we know stdout & stderr go to the proper log and/or normal files.  Not sure if it does the same with .run.
  * there is no testing coverage of this callback... which is why we don't know what it does, or whether it works in various cases.
  * the rudimentary API appends the file name to the configured command... so the filename to process must be the last argument to the configured command... would be more flexible to have a substitution mechanism. Example:
  
```
      run_work_item cp %f /myother/directory
      callback run
```

This is probably one of the easiest routes to being integrated into user workflows, kind of an easy gateway, so getting this method robust would probably accellerate many requests for data.

comment.body:
* for substitution, that was just one possible syntax... not sure what other ones could be thought of.
* could also have os.path.expandvars, and expanduser applied.

issue.title: do transfer (download and send) via memory... without saving to local file...

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
I think @reidsunderland was talking about this. Someone has a case where they want to transfer from an upstream source to a downstream destination. They don't want to write the file locally, because it's essentially just a buffer for the transfer.

Was talking today with a client, and they want this for S3 uploading... that is, download the file to a buffer, and then upload each buffer to the destination.

I think this could be done with an subscribe, by sub-classing sarracenia.transfer class, to override the on_data entry point to write the data to a pre-established output file descriptor.

along with a flowcb to:
* on_start to establish a connection to S3...
* after_accept to create/open the new object/file establish the file descriptor for the on_data to write to.
* after_work to close the completed object/file.
*on_stop to tear down the connection.

So that way, the entire transfer is only using one memory buffer.
 
anyways, that's one guess at how to do it... it might be wrong.

including: llvm, libboost, matplotlib, scipy, pandas, openblas  ... I guess the good side is performance is likely to be good because there is a lot of leveraging of high performance C libraries. There is also tornado? you need
a web framework to use a file system?  In total, it's pulling in 883 MB of dependencies.

Looking at redhat8, it does not show up at all.... so installing on redhat involves establishing a large venv (with a few gb of parallel environment for dependencies) or going with one of the python distributions like Anaconda.  

In a Scientific python context, this actually isn't bad... most of this stuff should be on hand anyways.  Sarracenia is often deployed as a system tool, however, not an application, and getting it installed at system level, such large dependencies will give a lot of people pause.

issue.title: do transfer (download and send) via memory... without saving to local file...

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
I think @reidsunderland was talking about this. Someone has a case where they want to transfer from an upstream source to a downstream destination. They don't want to write the file locally, because it's essentially just a buffer for the transfer.

Was talking today with a client, and they want this for S3 uploading... that is, download the file to a buffer, and then upload each buffer to the destination.

I think this could be done with an subscribe, by sub-classing sarracenia.transfer class, to override the on_data entry point to write the data to a pre-established output file descriptor.

along with a flowcb to:
* on_start to establish a connection to S3...
* after_accept to create/open the new object/file establish the file descriptor for the on_data to write to.
* after_work to close the completed object/file.
*on_stop to tear down the connection.

So that way, the entire transfer is only using one memory buffer.
 
anyways, that's one guess at how to do it... it might be wrong.

comment.body:
note that for most of our purposes, we want to save locally, because there are 10 destinations for each source product, so going via memory would mean retrieving from source 10 times.  So it's not great for many cases,
but in cases, where we truly deliver to one location, and where if the downstream is having an issue, it is ok to be bothering upstream, then this model is helpful.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body: To help with decommissioning Sundew, but not lose interop with MM, then we could make a sender/receiver for AM sockets...

comment.body: The stuff being put in the AM header is the ONLY way to separate the bulletins.  The AM header gives the length of the message in bytes. and you have to read that many bytes and then stop.  Any later bytes are the start of the header of the next message,... If you don't read the right number of bytes... it is hopeless... you will miss the header and I don't think there is any way to re-sync, and AM protocol doesn't have any elements that would allow a re-sync.  You need to parse the header correctly, assign the bytes correctly.

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... so the  management ui does not work at all in this case, sr sanity will kill it, 
status says they are stray, audit does not work... etc...

Question: what should we do in this case?

options:


Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
---------------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way. Make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
----------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.

Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?
(guess: subscribe, unless component directory provided? ... option add a "--component" command line option, which defaults to "subscribe" )

trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body:
so sarra runs per user... when you do sr_subscribe start xx   it is running as your current user, not root.  What is the meaning of the files in /etc/sr3 ?  to provide site defaults, I guess? Other reasons?

so... today... we match ~/.config/sr3/x/y with the state files in ~/.cache/sr3/x/y   where we put state files (recording the .pid, queue file name, persist the cache, etc...) in this new search path world, what does sr3 status show?

All configs in every part of the search path?   when someone does a *foreground* or a *start* and the config file is NOT in the ~/.config tree, I guess we should copy it there once we find it... and then sr status and friends will work unchanged... 

Is that the right idea? or should there be some other way of doing things.

issue.title: AM protocol driver

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body: To help with decommissioning Sundew, but not lose interop with MM, then we could make a sender/receiver for AM sockets...

comment.body:
So @kurt2x has a long standing wish to have an amserver, like on MetManager, where anyone just connects to a socket, and starts sending data.  with Sundew, we never had that, one would just pick a port, and a single process (pxReceiver) would service a single connection on the defined port.

What @andreleblanc11 has implemented right now is like pxReceiver, it accepts a single connection and processes it.  To get amserver like behaviour, we need to follow the traditional (if obscure) C daemon service pattern (looking for links, I gave @andreleblanc11 one in teams, but can't find it now...)


to recap... what is needed for the amserver "forking" issue:

* in the on_start it does a bind. ONCE! then it loops:
   * it then does an accept.
   * increment an instance id for the child's use...
   * then you pid=fork().
   * the parent (pid!=0) then needs to:
        * close the accepted socket. and 
        * loop around again waiting on the next accept... (not bind.)
   * The child (pid==0) then needs to:
       * change to use the given instance id... which means:
       * logging to a file with the correct instance id.
       * writing the pid file for the instance, so that sr status|stop|sanity will find it.
       *then exit the loop and start processing messages...

so... all the instance and log stuff is set up in instance.py ... which calls flow.. so it isn't immediately obvious how to call the instance stuff from a flow... sigh... food for thought.
perhaps @reidsunderland has some ideas.

the log setup logic is kind of painful, it's in sarracenia.instance.start() ... I guess we can copy/paste, or might need to re-factor a bit...

issue.title: hierarchical configurations (getting rid of "components")

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

issue.body:
In the Development meeting on 2022/03/28, it was like a light-bulb was suddenly lit, and people understood that all the components are just the flow algorithm with different defaults for different settings.  People noted:
* it was hard to understand what "a component" is.
* It was kind of cool that they were all implemented by sub-classing sarracenia.flow.

Consensus seemed to be that getting rid of the concept of components would be a win.  but it's a bit late in the sr3 cycle for that.
(and it wasn't really possible until all the 1st round of re-factors was done, because it wasn't until the last re-factor of poll that this became true.  until then poll was a huge outlier in the sub-classing of flow, but now that flowcb/poll/__init__.py has taken the main body of poll, the ¨poll¨ flow is just a selection of callbacks, like the other components.  so now it should be possible.

comment.body:
so this is implemented in #575... the thing I noticed is that there are very common configurations, senders, watches, etc... and if we have a sub-directory for them, that denotes the same information as the include, but the name of the configuration does not have that information... so in many cases you end up writing configuration files named:   sender_....  that contain the option *include sender.inc*  so you are writing "sender" twice... which is worse from a DRY perspective.

ie.
You could have a:
```

      sender/hoho.conf
                <contains a normal sender config>

```

vs.

```
     sender_hoho.conf
                 include sender.inc
                <contains a normal sender config>

```
So in a very common case, you end up writing the component name twice instead of once.
big deal? dunno... 

hmm...I'm thinking to keep the directory stuff around as shorthand... 
* if the *last* directory in the config path matches a sub-class, then it is assumed to be that kind of flow.
* if not it defaults to a parent class (Flow) (or explicit specification with flowMain option.)

so then you can group things like:

```
    pitcher_use_case/
                          watch/
                                  server.conf
                                  client.conf
                        sender/
                                  push.conf
                       subscribe/
                                  pull.conf
                      bobo.conf
                      lala/
                              fifi.conf
```

resulting in sr status showing lines like:
```

pitcher_use_case/watch/server
pitcher_use_case/watch/client
pitcher_use_case/sender/push
pitcher_use_case/subscribe/pull
pitcher_use_case/flow/bobo
pitcher_use_case/lala/flow/fifi


```
optionally bobo and fifi could be in flow sub-directories...

but the idea of keeping both around, in the current implementation results in two implementations of shovel, winnow, report, post, and watch... DRY again... do we write more code to get rid of it?

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... so the  management ui does not work at all in this case, sr sanity will kill it, 
status says they are stray, audit does not work... etc...

Question: what should we do in this case?

options:


Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
---------------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way. Make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
----------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.

Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?
(guess: subscribe, unless component directory provided? ... option add a "--component" command line option, which defaults to "subscribe" )

trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body: Another question is there is a rudimentary search path for sr config files... should there be a formal search path? SR_CONFIG_PATH ? or something like that? and look in those directories when resolving an *include" ...

OK, people should have a look at the latest commit... and think if this is what people want?
Now the configuration is completely universal... a config file like:
```

flowMain subscribe

```

is a default subscriber file... in fact that is the content of the subscribe.inc file included in the last commit.  so all the old components can kind of disappear, and everything just becomes a flow,

hmm... could do that... dunno...

comment.body:
OK so I sat with @andreleblanc11  yesterday and we pair programmed for a bit.  He now has a flowcb plugin that works for accepting messages from a single connection, writing them to a file in a configured directory, and posting a message for the resultant local file.  We had to comment out the poll initialization in order to get it to work for our example, because:

* If we add that plugin into a poll, a poll wants to have a transfer protocol (that it connects to to list files on the remove resource.) so since there is no transfer protocol to connect to, the init fails.

* If we add it as a plugin into a shovel (or subscribe, or sarra, or winnow.) it wants a broker to connect to for upstream messages... so the connection to the upstream broker fails on startup.

* If we add it as a plugin for watch... hey that might work... we just have a watch with a plugin that writes to the watch directory... but again... it would be a watch with no watch... 

* we could try to use the parent class (sarracenia.flow) without any sub-class... but the whole cli is built around the concept of "component/config" (which is already something being called into question in: #575, and #494 ) 
*  we could add special logic for "flow" to be an implicit component, and call them flows.
*  to avoid having to deal with "no-component",  we could invent a kind of "vanilla" flow... a flow class with no default plugins.    That would start up, and run... but currently we have no way of using a something that isn't a "component" so we need to invent a new "vanilla" component?  "plain?" 
* We could do is just make a sub-class for Andre's thing am becomes a new components sr3 start amserver.

dunno... lots of options.. not sure which way to do... so far the most attractive thing to me is to futz with "flow" as an implicit component...

issue.body:
currently we use poll for remote resources, via sftp, ftp, and http with various web services.
For local file systems, we can use linux INOTIFY kernel facility, except in some case that does not work (e.g: in HPC where file i/o can happen on many nodes and must have watch running on all nodes as a consequence)  so we have the force_polling option in watch... which seems odd given the existence of the poll component... why don't we just use that? indeed... 

Need to investigate whether polling with a destination as a file url works, and if so, document it as another option.

It  seems inelegant for this not to work.

issue.title: should we make greater use of pathlib?

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

labels.name: Refactor
labels.description: change implementation of existing functionality.

issue.body:
The pythonic (>3.6) way to deal with paths, is to use pathlib, and Path objects. Path objects make paths for the current platform, but relative paths that go into messages are supposed to be standard (ie. use the forward slash, not backward.) so using pathlib on windows to create messages will result in different messages.  We want to create portable paths, not platform specific ones.

Would it be better to look at places where paths are manipulated and use paths.  It is used in a few places where final local filenames are created, but most of the code uses strings, out of fear and because the old code is pre 3.6.

commits.message: Reworked `sr3 stop` to use dangerWillRobinson as discussed https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/pull/578

pull_request.title: Reworked `sr3 stop` to use dangerWillRobinson
pull_request.body:
`sr3 stop` will never stop foreground instances, even if you specify `component/config`. A message is printed to let the user know about running foreground configs that were not stopped, and that they can use `--dangerWillRobinson` to stop them.

`sr3 stop --dangerWillRobinson` will always stop running foreground instances (in addition to daemon instances).

Also found that there was a piece missing from previous changes that I made to `sr3 stop`'s behavior. If the stop method started attempting to SIGKILL processes, it would report that foreground instances were not responding to SIGKILL, even though it was not trying to SIGKILL them. Now the processes that are not responding to SIGKILL are correctly reported (only daemone

issue.body:
In the Development meeting on 2022/03/28, it was like a light-bulb was suddenly lit, and people understood that all the components are just the flow algorithm with different defaults for different settings.  People noted:
* it was hard to understand what "a component" is.
* It was kind of cool that they were all implemented by sub-classing sarracenia.flow.

Consensus seemed to be that getting rid of the concept of components would be a win.  but it's a bit late in the sr3 cycle for that.
(and it wasn't really possible until all the 1st round of re-factors was done, because it wasn't until the last re-factor of poll that this became true.  until then poll was a huge outlier in the sub-classing of flow, but now that flowcb/poll/__init__.py has taken the main body of poll, the ¨poll¨ flow is just a selection of callbacks, like the other components.  so now it should be possible.

issue.body:
right now, the batch for gathering, and for transfer protocols are based on the same *batch* setting.
The decision of batch sizing for messages to gather at once for processing and the number of files to transfer before tearing down and re-establishing the connection, are independent, and using the same setting seems wrong.

likely there should be two separate settings.

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... Question: what should we do in this case?

options:

Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
--------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way.
make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
-------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the 
version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy
of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.
Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?


trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body: would be great to group co-dependent examples as trees of configuration files, instead of just individual examples in component directories.

comment.body:
so say somebody gives a cli:
```

% sr3 foreground kk.conf

```
kk.conf is a file in the current directory (call it the local version)

in option 2, one would assume that kk.conf is a subscribe, and therefore copy it to ~/.config/sr3/subscribe/kk.conf, and then run foreground normally.  If there already is a kk.conf in ~/.config/sr3/subsscribe? what do we do?

a) always copy the local one to config tree... (so the user does his editing normally, and when they restart it takes effect... which sounds sugary to me.) .... this is an implicit "add" ... equivalent to sr3 add kk.conf... followed by sr3 foreground subscribe/kk.conf ... hmm...

b) check the mtime of the local and config tree copies... only copy if the local one is newer... (same sugar as option b.)

c) ignore local copy if config version exists... insists on use of cli "edit" command to take effect. (no sugar, adds friction... that user must use cli "edit" interface.)


```

sr3 foreground poll/kk.conf subscribe/kk.conf

```

similar but extended for more files and components assuming you have subdirectories for configurations.

```

mynet/   
           poll/mynet.conf
           sarra/mynet.conf

```

could have a sub-directory and accept the entire tree....copy they entire tree to config tree... 
starts to resemble #494.

issue.title: poll behaviour in vip... not working quite right.
issue.body:
as part of working on https://github.com/MetPX/sr_insects/issues/16 In the flakey_broker test, we simulate the failure of two poll configurations that differ by their vip setting.  when the broker is shut down as part of the flakey_broker test, the vip settings of the two polls are exchanged, so that the active and passive roles of the two configurations are switched.  This role switch is repeated for each of the the broker shutdowns.

It has become clear that poll isn't dealing with broker failures quite right....

this is the initial problem statement from that issue:
```

 poll sftp_f62 posted 659  sftp_f63 posted 198 
test 20 FAILURE: poll sftp_f62+3	 (857) should have the same number of items of sender	 (1120)
test 21 success: poll sftp_f62+3	 (857) should see the same number of items as poll sftp_f62 posted	 (857)
test 22 FAILURE: subscribe q_f71	 (1714) should have the same number of items as poll sftp_f62+3 (857)

```

part1: noticed redundant posting (both participants in the poll posting):
```

fractal% grep 'after_post posted' poll_sftp_f63_01.log | sed "s/.*'path': '//" | sed "s/'.*//" | sort >poll_f63_posted_sorted.list
fractal% 
fractal% grep 'after_post posted' poll_sftp_f62_01.log | sed "s/.*'path': '//" | sed "s/'.*//" | sort >poll_f62_posted_sorted.list
comm -12 poll_f62_posted_sorted.list poll_f63_posted_sorted.list | wc -l

```
went into the log directory (~/.cache/sr3/log) after a run, and the above snippet prints the paths of files posted by each polling configuration.  Since the list is not zero... there is some redundant posting going on.

issue.title: review & further document flowcb/run.py

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

issue.body:
There was a long-standing wish for a generalized "please invoke this arbitrary script or binary" on receipt of a file or in other circumstances.  for sr3 we now have a first pass at such a module, called Flowcb.Run Please look at the source
for how it is used:

 https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/blob/v03_wip/sarracenia/flowcb/run.py

Questions:
  * currently uses subprocess.Popen for running per file stuff, but subprocess.run for other cases.  Are both necessary? do they work the same? example, with popen, we know stdout & stderr go to the proper log and/or normal files.  Not sure if it does the same with .run.
  * there is no testing coverage of this callback... which is why we don't know what it does, or whether it works in various cases.
  * the rudimentary API appends the file name to the configured command... so the filename to process must be the last argument to the configured command... would be more flexible to have a substitution mechanism. Example:
  
```
      run_work_item cp %f /myother/directory
      callback run
```

This is probably one of the easiest routes to being integrated into user workflows, kind of an easy gateway, so getting this method robust would probably accellerate many requests for data.

comment.body:
* for substitution, that was just one possible syntax... not sure what other ones could be thought of.
* could also have os.path.expandvars, and expanduser applied.

issue.title: do transfer (download and send) via memory... without saving to local file...

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
I think @reidsunderland was talking about this. Someone has a case where they want to transfer from an upstream source to a downstream destination. They don't want to write the file locally, because it's essentially just a buffer for the transfer.

Was talking today with a client, and they want this for S3 uploading... that is, download the file to a buffer, and then upload each buffer to the destination.

I think this could be done with an subscribe, by sub-classing sarracenia.transfer class, to override the on_data entry point to write the data to a pre-established output file descriptor.

along with a flowcb to:
* on_start to establish a connection to S3...
* after_accept to create/open the new object/file establish the file descriptor for the on_data to write to.
* after_work to close the completed object/file.
*on_stop to tear down the connection.

So that way, the entire transfer is only using one memory buffer.
 
anyways, that's one guess at how to do it... it might be wrong.

a web framework to use a file system?  In total, it's pulling in 883 MB of dependencies.

Looking at redhat8, it does not show up at all.... so installing on redhat involves establishing a large venv (with a few gb of parallel environment for dependencies) or going with one of the python distributions like Anaconda.  

In a Scientific python context, this actually isn't bad... most of this stuff should be on hand anyways.  Sarracenia is often deployed as a system tool, however, not an application, and getting it installed at system level, such large dependencies will give a lot of people pause.

issue.title: do transfer (download and send) via memory... without saving to local file...

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
I think @reidsunderland was talking about this. Someone has a case where they want to transfer from an upstream source to a downstream destination. They don't want to write the file locally, because it's essentially just a buffer for the transfer.

Was talking today with a client, and they want this for S3 uploading... that is, download the file to a buffer, and then upload each buffer to the destination.

I think this could be done with an subscribe, by sub-classing sarracenia.transfer class, to override the on_data entry point to write the data to a pre-established output file descriptor.

along with a flowcb to:
* on_start to establish a connection to S3...
* after_accept to create/open the new object/file establish the file descriptor for the on_data to write to.
* after_work to close the completed object/file.
*on_stop to tear down the connection.

So that way, the entire transfer is only using one memory buffer.
 
anyways, that's one guess at how to do it... it might be wrong.

comment.body:
note that for most of our purposes, we want to save locally, because there are 10 destinations for each source product, so going via memory would mean retrieving from source 10 times.  So it's not great for many cases,
but in cases, where we truly deliver to one location, and where if the downstream is having an issue, it is ok to be bothering upstream, then this model is helpful.

issue.body: To help with decommissioning Sundew, but not lose interop with MM, then we could make a sender/receiver for AM sockets...

comment.body: The stuff being put in the AM header is the ONLY way to separate the bulletins.  The AM header gives the length of the message in bytes. and you have to read that many bytes and then stop.  Any later bytes are the start of the header of the next message,... If you don't read the right number of bytes... it is hopeless... you will miss the header and I don't think there is any way to re-sync, and AM protocol doesn't have any elements that would allow a re-sync.  You need to parse the header correctly, assign the bytes correctly.

issue.title: what to do with config files outside of the proper tree?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Extra attention is needed

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: UserStory
labels.description: interesting to read to consider improving

labels.name: Support
labels.description: not a defect, just someone needed some help.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Sugar
labels.description: nice to have features... not super important.

issue.body:
I have seen at least three cases with v2 where users get confusing results because the application really expects configuration files to be placed in the ~/.config/sr3/<component>/  directory.  For example: they use a file in their own directory, and then sr3 status says their processes are stray because it isn't in the tree... so the  management ui does not work at all in this case, sr sanity will kill it, 
status says they are stray, audit does not work... etc...

Question: what should we do in this case?

options:


Option 1: Insist on the .config tree
---------------------------------------------

Refuse to use the configuration unless it is in the correct tree.  give the user an error message hopefully pointing that way. Make sure that every file is only what is in the correct tree...

For many other apps, the storage of preferences in the config tree is completely invisible.
  
Option 2: Helpful
----------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.

Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?
(guess: subscribe, unless component directory provided? ... option add a "--component" command line option, which defaults to "subscribe" )

trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body:
so sarra runs per user... when you do sr_subscribe start xx   it is running as your current user, not root.  What is the meaning of the files in /etc/sr3 ?  to provide site defaults, I guess? Other reasons?

so... today... we match ~/.config/sr3/x/y with the state files in ~/.cache/sr3/x/y   where we put state files (recording the .pid, queue file name, persist the cache, etc...) in this new search path world, what does sr3 status show?

All configs in every part of the search path?   when someone does a *foreground* or a *start* and the config file is NOT in the ~/.config tree, I guess we should copy it there once we find it... and then sr status and friends will work unchanged... 

Is that the right idea? or should there be some other way of doing things.

issue.title: AM protocol driver

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body: To help with decommissioning Sundew, but not lose interop with MM, then we could make a sender/receiver for AM sockets...

comment.body:
So @kurt2x has a long standing wish to have an amserver, like on MetManager, where anyone just connects to a socket, and starts sending data.  with Sundew, we never had that, one would just pick a port, and a single process (pxReceiver) would service a single connection on the defined port.

What @andreleblanc11 has implemented right now is like pxReceiver, it accepts a single connection and processes it.  To get amserver like behaviour, we need to follow the traditional (if obscure) C daemon service pattern (looking for links, I gave @andreleblanc11 one in teams, but can't find it now...)


to recap... what is needed for the amserver "forking" issue:

* in the on_start it does a bind. ONCE! then it loops:
   * it then does an accept.
   * increment an instance id for the child's use...
   * then you pid=fork().
   * the parent (pid!=0) then needs to:
        * close the accepted socket. and 
        * loop around again waiting on the next accept... (not bind.)
   * The child (pid==0) then needs to:
       * change to use the given instance id... which means:
       * logging to a file with the correct instance id.
       * writing the pid file for the instance, so that sr status|stop|sanity will find it.
       *then exit the loop and start processing messages...

so... all the instance and log stuff is set up in instance.py ... which calls flow.. so it isn't immediately obvious how to call the instance stuff from a flow... sigh... food for thought.
perhaps @reidsunderland has some ideas.

the log setup logic is kind of painful, it's in sarracenia.instance.start() ... I guess we can copy/paste, or might need to re-factor a bit...

issue.title: hierarchical configurations (getting rid of "components")

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

issue.body:
In the Development meeting on 2022/03/28, it was like a light-bulb was suddenly lit, and people understood that all the components are just the flow algorithm with different defaults for different settings.  People noted:
* it was hard to understand what "a component" is.
* It was kind of cool that they were all implemented by sub-classing sarracenia.flow.

Consensus seemed to be that getting rid of the concept of components would be a win.  but it's a bit late in the sr3 cycle for that.
(and it wasn't really possible until all the 1st round of re-factors was done, because it wasn't until the last re-factor of poll that this became true.  until then poll was a huge outlier in the sub-classing of flow, but now that flowcb/poll/__init__.py has taken the main body of poll, the ¨poll¨ flow is just a selection of callbacks, like the other components.  so now it should be possible.

comment.body:
so this is implemented in #575... the thing I noticed is that there are very common configurations, senders, watches, etc... and if we have a sub-directory for them, that denotes the same information as the include, but the name of the configuration does not have that information... so in many cases you end up writing configuration files named:   sender_....  that contain the option *include sender.inc*  so you are writing "sender" twice... which is worse from a DRY perspective.

ie.
You could have a:
```

      sender/hoho.conf
                <contains a normal sender config>

```

vs.

```
     sender_hoho.conf
                 include sender.inc
                <contains a normal sender config>

```
So in a very common case, you end up writing the component name twice instead of once.
big deal? dunno... 

hmm...I'm thinking to keep the directory stuff around as shorthand... 
* if the *last* directory in the config path matches a sub-class, then it is assumed to be that kind of flow.
* if not it defaults to a parent class (Flow) (or explicit specification with flowMain option.)

so then you can group things like:

```
    pitcher_use_case/
                          watch/
                                  server.conf
                                  client.conf
                        sender/
                                  push.conf
                       subscribe/
                                  pull.conf
                      bobo.conf
                      lala/
                              fifi.conf
```

resulting in sr status showing lines like:
```

pitcher_use_case/watch/server
pitcher_use_case/watch/client
pitcher_use_case/sender/push
pitcher_use_case/subscribe/pull
pitcher_use_case/flow/bobo
pitcher_use_case/lala/flow/fifi


```
optionally bobo and fifi could be in flow sub-directories...

but the idea of keeping both around, in the current implementation results in two implementations of shovel, winnow, report, post, and watch... DRY again... do we write more code to get rid of it?

commits.message: basic documentation for flowMain and the include files for #575

----------------------

Silently copy the file to the right place? (like an implicit *add*?) what if he edits it afterward, do we copy again, or use the version that is in the "right" place? or diff them, and update as required? This makes the configs a kind of built-in cache/copy of the user supplied file. Every time the user supplies the file, if it isn't in the normal tree, then copy it where it should be.

Problem: how do you know what component it is if you only have a file name?
(guess: subscribe, unless component directory provided? ... option add a "--component" command line option, which defaults to "subscribe" )

trying to figure out what will satisfy the principle of least astonishment for this case.

comment.body:
OK so I sat with @andreleblanc11  yesterday and we pair programmed for a bit.  He now has a flowcb plugin that works for accepting messages from a single connection, writing them to a file in a configured directory, and posting a message for the resultant local file.  We had to comment out the poll initialization in order to get it to work for our example, because:

* If we add that plugin into a poll, a poll wants to have a transfer protocol (that it connects to to list files on the remove resource.) so since there is no transfer protocol to connect to, the init fails.

* If we add it as a plugin into a shovel (or subscribe, or sarra, or winnow.) it wants a broker to connect to for upstream messages... so the connection to the upstream broker fails on startup.

* If we add it as a plugin for watch... hey that might work... we just have a watch with a plugin that writes to the watch directory... but again... it would be a watch with no watch... 

* we could try to use the parent class (sarracenia.flow) without any sub-class... but the whole cli is built around the concept of "component/config" (which is already something being called into question in: #575, and #494 ) 
*  we could add special logic for "flow" to be an implicit component, and call them flows.
*  to avoid having to deal with "no-component",  we could invent a kind of "vanilla" flow... a flow class with no default plugins.    That would start up, and run... but currently we have no way of using a something that isn't a "component" so we need to invent a new "vanilla" component?  "plain?" 
* We could do is just make a sub-class for Andre's thing am becomes a new components sr3 start amserver.

dunno... lots of options.. not sure which way to do... so far the most attractive thing to me is to futz with "flow" as an implicit component...

currently we use poll for remote resources, via sftp, ftp, and http with various web services.
For local file systems, we can use linux INOTIFY kernel facility, except in some case that does not work (e.g: in HPC where file i/o can happen on many nodes and must have watch running on all nodes as a consequence)  so we have the force_polling option in watch... which seems odd given the existence of the poll component... why don't we just use that? indeed...

issue.title: should we make greater use of pathlib?

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: v3only
labels.description: Only affects v3 branches.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

labels.name: Refactor
labels.description: change implementation of existing functionality.

issue.body:
The pythonic (>3.6) way to deal with paths, is to use pathlib, and Path objects. Path objects make paths for the current platform, but relative paths that go into messages are supposed to be standard (ie. use the forward slash, not backward.) so using pathlib on windows to create messages will result in different messages.  We want to create portable paths, not platform specific ones.

Would it be better to look at places where paths are manipulated and use paths.  It is used in a few places where final local filenames are created, but most of the code uses strings, out of fear and because the old code is pre 3.6.

commits.message: Reworked `sr3 stop` to use dangerWillRobinson as discussed https://github.com/MetPX/sarracenia/pull/578

pull_request.title: Reworked `sr3 stop` to use dangerWillRobinson
pull_request.body:
`sr3 stop` will never stop foreground instances, even if you specify `component/config`. A message is printed to let the user know about running foreground configs that were not stopped, and that they can use `--dangerWillRobinson` to stop them.

`sr3 stop --dangerWillRobinson` will always stop running foreground instances (in addition to daemon instances).

Also found that there was a piece missing from previous changes that I made to `sr3 stop`'s behavior. If the stop method started attempting to SIGKILL processes, it would report that foreground instances were not responding to SIGKILL, even though it was not trying to SIGKILL them. Now the processes that are not responding to SIGKILL are correctly reported (only daemone

issue.body:
In the Development meeting on 2022/03/28, it was like a light-bulb was suddenly lit, and people understood that all the components are just the flow algorithm with different defaults for different settings.  People noted:
* it was hard to understand what "a component" is.
* It was kind of cool that they were all implemented by sub-classing sarracenia.flow.

Consensus seemed to be that getting rid of the concept of components would be a win.  but it's a bit late in the sr3 cycle for that.
(and it wasn't really possible until all the 1st round of re-factors was done, because it wasn't until the last re-factor of poll that this became true.  until then poll was a huge outlier in the sub-classing of flow, but now that flowcb/poll/__init__.py has taken the main body of poll, the ¨poll¨ flow is just a selection of callbacks, like the other components.  so now it should be possible.

issue.body:
right now, the batch for gathering, and for transfer protocols are based on the same *batch* setting.

issue.title: add "diagram" mode, to map out cluster configuration.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

issue.body:
It would be nice to have an automated way to have pretty pictures of configurations.
* There is the python diagram library, perhaps there are other means.
* sr.py has a global configuration including the entire tree of configurations within a cluster.

Someone could produce a python program to draw a diagram of the cluster config, based 
on the global configuraation as input.  then run the resulting code to get the diagram.

The linkages between configurations could be based on exchange == post_exchange...
and also based on directories (mapping "directory" and "path" or "destination" settings)
